play.title: The Second Part of Henry the Fourth

persona.persname: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

stagedir.dir: Enter Rumor, painted full of tongues.

speech.speaker: RUM.
speech.line: Open your ears; for which of you will stop
The vent of hearing when loud Rumor speaks?
I, from the orient to the drooping west
(Making the wind my post-horse), still unfold
The acts commenced on this ball of earth.
Upon my tongues continual slanders ride,
The which in every language I pronounce,
Stuffing the ears of men with false reports.
I speak of peace, while covert enmity
Under the smile of safety wounds the world;
And who but Rumor, who but only I,
Make fearful musters and prepar’d defense,
Whiles the big year, swoll’n with some other grief,
Is thought with child by the stern tyrant war,
And no such matter? Rumor is a pipe
Blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures,
And of so easy and so plain a stop
That the blunt monster with uncounted heads,
The still-discordant wav’ring multitude,
Can play upon it. But what need I thus
My well-known body to anatomize
Among my household? Why is Rumor here?
I run before King Harry’s victory,
Who in a bloody field by Shrewsbury
Hath beaten down young Hotspur and his troops,
Quenching the flame of bold rebellion
Even with the rebels’ blood. But what mean I
To speak so true at first? My office is
To noise abroad that Harry Monmouth fell
Under the wrath of noble Hotspur’s sword,
And that the King before the Douglas’ rage
Stoop’d his anointed head as low as death.
This have I rumor’d through the peasant towns
Between that royal field of Shrewsbury
And this worm-eaten hold of ragged stone,
Where Hotspur’s father, old Northumberland,
Lies crafty-sick. The posts come tiring on,
And not a man of them brings other news
Than they have learnt of me. From Rumor’s tongues
They bring smooth comforts false, worse than true wrongs.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Lord Bardolph at one door.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Who keeps the gate here ho?
Where is the Earl?

speech.speaker: PORT.
speech.line: What shall I say you are?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Tell thou the Earl
That the Lord Bardolph doth attend him here.

speech.speaker: PORT.
speech.line: His lordship is walk’d forth into the orchard.
Please it your honor knock but at the gate,
And he himself will answer.

stagedir.dir: Enter Henry Percy, the Earl Northumberland, in a night-cap and supporting himself with a staff.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: What news, Lord Bardolph? Every minute now
Should be the father of some stratagem.
The times are wild, contention, like a horse
Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loose,
And bears down all before him.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Noble Earl,
I bring you certain news from Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Good, and God will!

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: As good as heart can wish:
The King is almost wounded to the death,
And in the fortune of my lord your son,
Prince Harry slain outright, and both the Blunts
Kill’d by the hand of Douglas, young Prince John
And Westmorland and Stafford fled the field,
And Harry Monmouth’s brawn, the hulk Sir John,
Is prisoner to your son. O, such a day!
So fought, so followed, and so fairly won,
Came not till now to dignify the times,
Since Caesar’s fortunes.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: How is this deriv’d?
Saw you the field? Came you from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: I spake with one, my lord, that came from thence,
A gentleman well bred and of good name,
That freely rend’red me these news for true.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Here comes my servant Travers, who I sent
On Tuesday last to listen after news.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Yea, this man’s brow, like to a title-leaf,
Foretells the nature of a tragic volume.
So looks the strond whereon the imperious flood
Hath left a witness’d usurpation.
Say, Morton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: I ran from Shrewsbury, my noble lord,
Where hateful death put on his ugliest mask
To fright our party.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: How doth my son and brother?
Thou tremblest, and the whiteness in thy cheek
Is apter than thy tongue to tell thy arrand.
Even such a man, so faint, so spiritless,
So dull, so dead in look, so woe-begone,
Drew Priam’s curtain in the dead of night,
And would have told him half his Troy was burnt;
But Priam found the fire ere he his tongue,
And I my Percy’s death ere thou report’st it.
This thou wouldst say, “Your son did thus and thus;
Your brother thus; so fought the noble Douglas”—
Stopping my greedy ear with their bold deeds,
But in the end, to stop my ear indeed,
Thou hast a sigh to blow away this praise,
Ending with “Brother, son, and all are dead.”

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Douglas is living, and your brother yet,
But for my lord your son—

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Why, he is dead.
See what a ready tongue suspicion hath!
He that but fears the thing he would not know
Hath by instinct knowledge from others’ eyes
That what he fear’d is chanced. Yet speak, Morton,
Tell thou an earl his divination lies,
And I will take it as a sweet disgrace
And make thee rich for doing me such wrong.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: You are too great to be by me gainsaid,
Your spirit is too true, your fears too certain.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: Yet for all this, say not that Percy’s dead.
I see a strange confession in thine eye.
Thou shak’st thy head, and hold’st it fear or sin
To speak a truth. If he be slain, say so;
The tongue offends not that reports his death,
And he doth sin that doth belie the dead,
Not he which says the dead is not alive.
Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news
Hath but a losing office, and his tongue
Sounds ever after as a sullen bell,
Rememb’red tolling a departing friend.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: I cannot think, my lord, your son is dead.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: I am sorry I should force you to believe
That which I would to God I had not seen,
But these mine eyes saw him in bloody state,
Rend’ring faint quittance, wearied and outbreath’d,
To Harry Monmouth, whose swift wrath beat down
The never-daunted Percy to the earth,
From whence with life he never more sprung up.
In few, his death, whose spirit lent a fire
Even to the dullest peasant in his camp,
Being bruited once, took fire and heat away
From the best-temper’d courage in his troops,
For from his metal was his party steeled,
Which once in him abated, all the rest
Turn’d on themselves, like dull and heavy lead.
And as the thing that’s heavy in itself
Upon enforcement flies with greatest speed,
So did our men, heavy in Hotspur’s loss,
Lend to this weight such lightness with their fear
That arrows fled not swifter toward their aim
Than did our soldiers, aiming at their safety,
Fly from the field. Then was that noble Worcester
So soon ta’en prisoner, and that furious Scot,
The bloody Douglas, whose well-laboring sword
Had three times slain th’ appearance of the King,
Gan vail his stomach and did grace the shame
Of those that turn’d their backs, and in his flight,
Stumbling in fear, was took. The sum of all
Is that the King hath won, and hath sent out
A speedy power to encounter you, my lord,
Under the conduct of young Lancaster
And Westmorland. This is the news at full.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: For this I shall have time enough to mourn;
In poison there is physic, and these news,
Having been well, that would have made me sick,
Being sick, have (in some measure) made me well.
And as the wretch whose fever-weak’ned joints,
Like strengthless hinges, buckle under life,
Impatient of his fit, breaks like a fire
Out of his keeper’s arms, even so my limbs,
Weak’ned with grief, being now enrag’d with grief,
Are thrice themselves. Hence therefore, thou nice crutch!
A scaly gauntlet now with joints of steel
Must glove this hand; and hence, thou sickly coif!
That art a guard too wanton for the head
Which princes, flesh’d with conquest, aim to hit.
Now bind my brows with iron, and approach
The ragged’st hour that time and spite dare bring
To frown upon th’ enrag’d Northumberland!
Let heaven kiss earth! Now let not Nature’s hand
Keep the wild flood confin’d! Let order die!
And let this world no longer be a stage
To feed contention in a ling’ring act;
But let one spirit of the first-born Cain
Reign in all bosoms, that each heart being set
On bloody courses, the rude scene may end,
And darkness be the burier of the dead!

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: This strained passion doth you wrong, my lord.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Sweet Earl, divorce not wisdom from your honor,
The lives of all your loving complices
Lean on your health, the which, if you give o’er
To stormy passion, must perforce decay.
You cast th’ event of war, my noble lord,
And summ’d the accompt of chance before you said,
“Let us make head.” It was your presurmise
That in the dole of blows your son might drop.
You knew he walk’d o’er perils, on an edge,
More likely to fall in than to get o’er;
You were advis’d his flesh was capable
Of wounds and scars; and that his forward spirit
Would lift him where most trade of danger rang’d;
Yet did you say, “Go forth!” and none of this
(Though strongly apprehended) could restrain
The stiff-borne action. What hath then befall’n?
Or what doth this bold enterprise bring forth
More than that being which was like to be?

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: We all that are engaged to this loss
Knew that we ventured on such dangerous seas
That if we wrought out life ’twas ten to one,
And yet we ventur’d for the gain propos’d,
Chok’d the respect of likely peril fear’d,
And since we are o’erset, venture again.
Come, we will all put forth, body and goods.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: ’Tis more than time, and, my most noble lord,
I hear for certain and dare speak the truth,
The gentle Archbishop of York is up
With well-appointed pow’rs. He is a man
Who with a double surety binds his followers.
My lord your son had only but the corpse’,
But shadows and the shows of men, to fight;
For that same word, rebellion, did divide
The action of their bodies from their souls,
And they did fight with queasiness, constrain’d
As men drink potions, that their weapons only
Seem’d on our side; but for their spirits and souls,
This word, rebellion, it had froze them up,
As fish are in a pond. But now the Bishop
Turns insurrection to religion.
Suppos’d sincere and holy in his thoughts,
He’s follow’d both with body and with mind;
And doth enlarge his rising with the blood
Of fair King Richard, scrap’d from Pomfret stones;
Derives from heaven his quarrel and his cause;
Tells them he doth bestride a bleeding land,
Gasping for life under great Bullingbrook,
And more and less do flock to follow him.

speech.speaker: NORTH.
speech.line: I knew of this before, but to speak truth,
This present grief had wip’d it from my mind.
Go in with me, and counsel every man
The aptest way for safety and revenge.
Get posts and letters, and make friends with speed—
Never so few, and never yet more need.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

stagedir.dir: Enter Sir John Falstaff alone, with his Page, following behind, bearing his sword and buckler.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir, here comes the nobleman that committed the Prince for striking him about Bardolph.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Wait close, I will not see him.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What’s he that goes there?

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Falstaff, and’t please your lordship.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: He that was in question for the robb’ry?

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: He, my lord, but he hath since done good service at Shrewsbury, and (as I hear) is now going with some charge to the Lord John of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What, to York? Call him back again.

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir John Falstaff!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Boy, tell him I am deaf.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: You must speak louder, my master is deaf.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I am sure he is, to the hearing of any thing good. Go pluck him by the elbow, I must speak with him.

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir John!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What? A young knave, and begging? Is there not wars? Is there not employment? Doth not the King lack subjects? Do not the rebels need soldiers? Though it be a shame to be on any side but one, it is worse shame to beg than to be on the worst side, were it worse than the name of rebellion can tell how to make it.

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: You mistake me, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Why, sir, did I say you were an honest man? Setting my knighthood and my soldiership aside, I had lied in my throat if I had said so.

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: I pray you, sir, then set your knighthood and your soldiership aside, and give me leave to tell you you lie in your throat if you say I am any other than an honest man.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I give thee leave to tell me so? I lay aside that which grows to me? If thou get’st any leave of me, hang me; if thou tak’st leave, thou wert better be hang’d. You hunt counter, hence, avaunt!

speaker.long: Servant to the Lord Chief Justice

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: Sir, my lord would speak with you.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John Falstaff, a word with you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My good lord! God give your lordship good time of day. I am glad to see your lordship abroad. I heard say your lordship was sick, I hope your lordship goes abroad by advice. Your lordship, though not clean past your youth, have yet some smack of an ague in you, some relish of the saltness of time in you, and I most humbly beseech your lordship to have a reverend care of your health.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, I sent for you before your expedition to Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And’t please your lordship, I hear his Majesty is return’d with some discomfort from Wales.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I talk not of his Majesty. You would not come when I sent for you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: And I hear, moreover, his Highness is fall’n into this same whoreson apoplexy.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, God mend him! I pray you let me speak with you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: This apoplexy, as I take it, is a kind of lethargy, and’t please your lordship, a kind of sleeping in the blood, a whoreson tingling.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What tell you me of it? Be it as it is.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: It hath it original from much grief, from study, and perturbation of the brain. I have read the cause of his effects in Galen, it is a kind of deafness.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I think you are fall’n into the disease, for you hear not what I say to you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Very well, my lord, very well. Rather, and’t please you, it is the disease of not list’ning, the malady of not marking, that I am troubled withal.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: To punish you by the heels would amend the attention of your ears, and I care not if I do become your physician.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am as poor as Job, my lord, but not so patient. Your lordship may minister the potion of imprisonment to me in respect of poverty, but how I should be your patient to follow your prescriptions, the wise may make some dram of a scruple, or indeed a scruple itself.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I sent for you, when there were matters against you for your life, to come speak with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I was then advis’d by my learned counsel in the laws of this land-service, I did not come.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, the truth is, Sir John, you live in great infamy.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: He that buckles himself in my belt cannot live in less.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Your means are very slender, and your waste is great.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would it were otherwise, I would my means were greater and my waist slenderer.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You have misled the youthful prince.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: The young prince hath misled me. I am the fellow with the great belly, and he my dog.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Well, I am loath to gall a new-heal’d wound. Your day’s service at Shrewsbury hath a little gilded over your night’s exploit on Gadshill. You may thank th’ unquiet time for your quiet o’erposting that action.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: But since all is well, keep it so, wake not a sleeping wolf.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: To wake a wolf is as bad as smell a fox.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What, you are as a candle, the better part burnt out.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: A wassail candle, my lord, all tallow; if I did say of wax, my growth would approve the truth.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: There is not a white hair in your face but should have his effect of gravity.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: His effect of gravy, gravy, gravy.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You follow the young prince up and down, like his ill angel.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Not so, my lord. Your ill angel is light, but I hope he that looks upon me will take me without weighing, and yet in some respects I grant I cannot go. I cannot tell. Virtue is of so little regard in these costermongers’ times that true valor is turn’d berrord; pregnancy is made a tapster, and his quick wit wasted in giving reckonings; all the other gifts appertinent to man, as the malice of this age shapes them, are not worth a gooseberry. You that are old consider not the capacities of us that are young, you do measure the heat of our livers with the bitterness of your galls; and we that are in the vaward of our youth, I must confess, are wags too.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Do you set down your name in the scroll of youth, that are written down old with all the characters of age? Have you not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yellow cheek, a white beard, a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? Is not your voice broken, your wind short, your chin double, your wit single, and every part about you blasted with antiquity? And will you yet call yourself young? Fie, fie, fie, Sir John!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, I was born about three of the clock in the afternoon, with a white head and something a round belly. For my voice, I have lost it with hallowing and singing of anthems. To approve my youth further, I will not. The truth is, I am only old in judgment and understanding; and he that will caper with me for a thousand marks, let him lend me the money, and have at him! For the box of the year that the Prince gave you, he gave it like a rude prince, and you took it like a sensible lord. I have check’d him for it, and the young lion repents,

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: If I do, fillip me with a three-man beetle. A man can no more separate age and covetousness than ’a can part young limbs and lechery; but the gout galls the one, and the pox pinches the other, and so both the degrees prevent my curses. Boy!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What money is in my purse?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Seven groats and two pence.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I can get no remedy against this consumption of the purse; borrowing only lingers and lingers it out, but the disease is incurable. Go bear this letter to my Lord of Lancaster, this to the Prince, this to the Earl of Westmorland, and this to old Mistress Ursula, whom I have weekly sworn to marry since I perceiv’d the first white hair of my chin. About it, you know where to find me.

A pox of this gout! Or a gout of this pox! For the one or the other plays the rogue with my great toe. ’Tis no matter if I do halt, I have the wars for my color, and my pension shall seem the more reasonable. A good wit will make use of any thing. I will turn diseases to commodity.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Thus have you heard our cause and known our means,
And, my most noble friends, I pray you all
Speak plainly your opinions of our hopes.
And first, Lord Marshal, what say you to it?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: I well allow the occasion of our arms,
But gladly would be better satisfied
How in our means we should advance ourselves
To look with forehead bold and big enough
Upon the power and puissance of the King.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Our present musters grow upon the file
To five and twenty thousand men of choice,
And our supplies live largely in the hope
Of great Northumberland, whose bosom burns
With an incensed fire of injuries.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: The question then, Lord Hastings, standeth thus:
Whether our present five and twenty thousand
May hold up head without Northumberland?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: With him, we may.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Yea, marry, there’s the point!
But if without him we be thought too feeble,
My judgment is we should not step too far
Till we had his assistance by the hand.
For in a theme so bloody-fac’d as this,
Conjecture, expectation, and surmise
Of aids incertain should not be admitted.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: ’Tis very true, Lord Bardolph, for indeed
It was young Hotspur’s cause at Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: It was, my lord, who lin’d himself with hope,
Eating the air, and promise of supply,
Flatt’ring himself in project of a power
Much smaller than the smallest of his thoughts,
And so with great imagination,
Proper to madmen, led his powers to death,
And winking, leapt into destruction.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: But by your leave, it never yet did hurt
To lay down likelihoods and forms of hope.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Yes, if this present quality of war—
Indeed the instant action, a cause on foot—
Lives so in hope, as in an early spring
We see th’ appearing buds, which to prove fruit
Hope gives not so much warrant, as despair
That frosts will bite them. When we mean to build,
We first survey the plot, then draw the model,
And when we see the figure of the house,
Then must we rate the cost of the erection,
Which if we find outweighs ability,
What do we then but draw anew the model
In fewer offices, or at least desist
To build at all? Much more, in this great work
(Which is, almost, to pluck a kingdom down
And set another up), should we survey
The plot of situation and the model,
Consent upon a sure foundation,
Question surveyors, know our own estate,
How able such a work to undergo,
To weigh against his opposite; or else
We fortify in paper and in figures,
Using the names of men in stead of men,
Like one that draws the model of an house
Beyond his power to build it, who, half thorough,
Gives o’er, and leaves his part-created cost
A naked subject to the weeping clouds
And waste for churlish winter’s tyranny.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Grant that our hopes (yet likely of fair birth)
Should be still-born, and that we now possess’d
The utmost man of expectation,
I think we are so a body strong enough,
Even as we are, to equal with the King.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: What, is the King but five and twenty thousand?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: To us no more, nay, not so much, Lord Bardolph,
For his divisions, as the times do brawl,
Are in three heads: one power against the French,
And one against Glendower; perforce a third
Must take up us. So is the unfirm King
In three divided, and his coffers sound
With hollow poverty and emptiness.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: That he should draw his several strengths together,
And come against us in full puissance,
Need not to be dreaded.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: If he should do so,
To French and Welsh he leaves his back unarm’d,
They baying him at the heels. Never fear that.

speech.speaker: L. BARD.
speech.line: Who is it like should lead his forces hither?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: The Duke of Lancaster and Westmorland;
Against the Welsh, himself and Harry Monmouth;
But who is substituted against the French,
I have no certain notice.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Let us on!
And publish the occasion of our arms.
The commonwealth is sick of their own choice,
Their over-greedy love hath surfeited.
An habitation giddy and unsure
Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart.
O thou fond many, with what loud applause
Didst thou beat heaven with blessing Bullingbrook
Before he was what thou wouldst have him be!
And being now trimm’d in thine own desires,
Thou, beastly feeder, art so full of him,
That thou provok’st thyself to cast him up.
So, so, thou common dog, didst thou disgorge
Thy glutton bosom of the royal Richard,
And now thou wouldst eat thy dead vomit up,
And howl’st to find it. What trust is in these times?
They that, when Richard liv’d, would have him die,
Are now become enamor’d on his grave.
Thou, that threw’st dust upon his goodly head
When through proud London he came sighing on
After th’ admired heels of Bullingbrook,
Cri’st now, “O earth, yield us that king again,
And take thou this!” O thoughts of men accurs’d!
Past and to come seems best; things present worst.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Shall we go draw our numbers and set on?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: We are time’s subjects, and time bids be gone.

stagedir.dir: Enter Hostess Quickly of the Tavern and an officer or two—Fang and Snare, Snare lagging behind.

scene.line: Yonder he comes, and that arrant malmsey-nose knave, Bardolph, with him. Do your offices, do your offices, Master Fang and Master Snare, do me, do me, do me your offices.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: How now, whose mare’s dead? What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FANG.
speech.line: I arrest you at the suit of Mistress Quickly.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Away, varlets! Draw, Bardolph, cut me off the villain’s head, throw the quean in the channel.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Throw me in the channel? I’ll throw thee in the channel. Wilt thou? Wilt thou? Thou bastardly rogue! Murder, murder! Ah, thou honeysuckle villain! Wilt thou kill God’s officers and the King’s? Ah, thou honeyseed rogue! Thou art a honeyseed, a man-queller, and a woman-queller.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Keep them off, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: OFFICER.
speech.line: A rescue! A rescue!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Good people, bring a rescue or two.
Thou wo’t, wo’t thou? Thou wo’t, wo’t ta? Do, do, thou rogue! Do, thou hempseed!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Away, you scullion! You rampallian! You fustilarian! I’ll tickle your catastrophe.

stagedir.dir: Enter Lord Chief Justice and his Men.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What is the matter? Keep the peace here, ho!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Good my lord, be good to me; I beseech you stand to me.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: How now, Sir John? What are you brawling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and business?
You should have been well on your way to York.
Stand from him, fellow, wherefore hang’st thou upon him?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O my most worshipful lord, and’t please your Grace, I am a poor widow of Eastcheap, and he is arrested at my suit.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: For what sum?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: It is more than for some, my lord, it is for all I have. He hath eaten me out of house and home, he hath put all my substance into that fat belly of his, but I will have some of it out again, or I will ride thee a’ nights like the mare.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I think I am as like to ride the mare, if I have any vantage of ground to get up.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: How comes this, Sir John? What man of good temper would endure this tempest of exclamation? Are you not asham’d to enforce a poor widow to so rough a course to come by her own?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What is the gross sum that I owe thee?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Marry, if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the money too. Thou didst swear to me upon a parcel-gilt goblet, sitting in my Dauphin chamber, at the round table by a sea-coal fire, upon Wednesday in Wheeson week, when the Prince broke thy head for liking his father to a singing-man of Windsor, thou didst swear to me then, as I was washing thy wound, to marry me and make me my lady thy wife. Canst thou deny it? Did not goodwife Keech, the butcher’s wife, come in then and call me gossip Quickly? Coming in to borrow a mess of vinegar, telling us she had a good dish of prawns, whereby thou didst desire to eat some, whereby I told thee they were ill for a green wound? And didst thou not, when she was gone down stairs, desire me to be no more so familiarity with such poor people, saying that ere long they should call me madam? And didst thou not kiss me, and bid me fetch thee thirty shillings? I put thee now to thy book-oath. Deny it if thou canst.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, this is a poor mad soul, and she says up and down the town that her eldest son is like you. She hath been in good case, and the truth is, poverty hath distracted her. But for these foolish officers, I beseech you I may have redress against them.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, Sir John, I am well acquainted with your manner of wrenching the true cause the false way. It is not a confident brow, nor the throng of words that come with such more than impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from a level consideration. You have, as it appears to me, practic’d upon the easy-yielding spirit of this woman, and made her serve your uses both in purse and in person.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Yea, in truth, my lord.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Pray thee peace. Pay her the debt you owe her, and unpay the villainy you have done with her. The one you may do with sterling money, and the other with current repentance.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord, I will not undergo this sneap without reply. You call honorable boldness impudent sauciness; if a man will make curtsy and say nothing, he is virtuous. No, my lord, my humble duty rememb’red, I will not be your suitor. I say to you, I do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon hasty employment in the King’s affairs.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You speak as having power to do wrong, but answer in th’ effect of your reputation, and satisfy the poor woman.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come hither, hostess.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Now, Master Gower, what news?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: The King, my lord, and Harry Prince of Wales
Are near at hand. The rest the paper tells.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I am a gentleman!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Faith, you said so before.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: As I am a gentleman! Come, no more words of it.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By this heav’nly ground I tread on, I must be fain to pawn both my plate and the tapestry of my dining-chambers.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Glasses, glasses, is the only drinking, and for thy walls, a pretty slight drollery, or the story of the Prodigal, or the German hunting in waterwork, is worth a thousand of these bed-hangers and these fly-bitten tapestries. Let it be ten pound, if thou canst. Come, and ’twere not for thy humors, there’s not a better wench in England. Go wash thy face, and draw the action. Come, thou must not be in this humor with me, dost not know me? Come, come, I know thou wast set on to this.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Pray thee, Sir John, let it be but twenty nobles. I’ faith, I am loath to pawn my plate, so God save me law!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let it alone, I’ll make other shift. You’ll be a fool still.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Well, you shall have it, though I pawn my gown. I hope you’ll come to supper. You’ll pay me all together?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will I live?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: I have heard better news.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What’s the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Where lay the King tonight?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: At Basingstoke, my lord.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I hope, my lord, all’s well. What is the news, my lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Come all his forces back?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: No, fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse,
Are march’d up to my Lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland and the Archbishop.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: You shall have letters of me presently. Come, go along with me, good Master Gower.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My lord!

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to dinner?

speech.speaker: GOW.
speech.line: I must wait upon my good lord here, I thank you, good Sir John.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to take soldiers up in counties as you go.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will you sup with me, Master Gower?

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool that taught them me. This is the right fencing grace, my lord, tap for tap, and so part fair.

speech.speaker: CH. JUST.
speech.line: Now the Lord lighten thee! Thou art a great fool.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Prince Henry, Poins, with other.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And the boy that I gave Falstaff. ’A had him from me Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transform’d him ape.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: God save your Grace!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And yours, most noble Bardolph!

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool, must you be blushing? Wherefore blush you now? What a maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Is’t such a matter to get a pottle-pot’s maidenhead?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: ’A calls me e’en now, my lord, through a red lattice, and I could discern no part of his face from the window. At last I spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in the ale-wive’s petticoat and so peep’d through.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Has not the boy profited?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Away, you rascally Althaea’s dream, away!

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Instruct us, boy, what dream, boy?

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: Marry, my lord, Althaea dreamt she was deliver’d of a fire-brand, and therefore I call him her dream.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: A crown’s worth of good interpretation. There ’tis, boy.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: O that this blossom could be kept from cankers! Well, there is sixpence to preserve thee.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: And you do not make him hang’d among you, the gallows shall have wrong.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: And how doth thy master, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Well, my lord. He heard of your Grace’s coming to town. There’s a letter for you.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Deliver’d with good respect. And how doth the martlemas, your master?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: In bodily health, sir.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Marry, the immortal part needs a physician, but that moves not him; though that be sick, it dies not.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: I do allow this wen to be as familiar with me as my dog, and he holds his place, for look you how he writes.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: I warrant you, as common as the way between Saint Albons and London.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his true colors, and not ourselves be seen?

speech.speaker: POINS.
speech.line: Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait upon him at his table as drawers.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: From a God to a bull? A heavy descension! It was Jove’s case. From a prince to a prentice? A low transformation! That shall be mine, for in every thing the purpose must weigh with the folly. Follow me, Ned.

stagedir.dir: Enter Northumberland (Henry Percy), his wife, Lady Northumberland, and Lady Percy, the wife to Harry Percy.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: What the devil hast thou brought there? Apple-johns? Thou knowest Sir John cannot endure an apple-john.

speech.speaker: 2. DRAW.
speech.line: Mass, thou say’st true. The Prince once set a dish of apple-johns before him, and told him there were five more Sir Johns, and putting off his hat, said, “I will now take my leave of these six dry, round, old, wither’d knights.” It ang’red him to the heart, but he hath forgot that.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Why then cover and set them down, and see if thou canst find out Sneak’s noise. Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear some music.

speech.speaker: 3. DRAW.
speech.line: Dispatch. The room where they supp’d is too hot, they’ll come in straight.

speech.speaker: FRAN.
speech.line: Sirrah, here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon, and they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons, and Sir John must not know of it. Bardolph hath brought word.

speech.speaker: 3. DRAW.
speech.line: By the mass, here will be old utis, it will be an excellent stratagem.

speech.speaker: 2. DRAW.
speech.line: I’ll see if I can find out Sneak.

stagedir.dir: Enter Mistress Quickly the Hostess and Doll Tearsheet.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: “And was a worthy king.”
How now, Mistress Doll?

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Sick of a calm, yea, good faith.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: So is all her sect; and they be once in a calm, they are sick.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: A pox damn you, you muddy rascal, is that all the comfort you give me?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I make them? Gluttony and diseases make, I make them not.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to make the diseases, Doll. We catch of you, Doll, we catch of you. Grant that, my poor virtue, grant that.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: “Your brooches, pearls, and ouches.” For to serve bravely is to come halting off, you know; to come off the breach with his pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely; to venture upon the charg’d chambers bravely—

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: By my troth, this is the old fashion, you two never meet but you fall to some discord. You are both, i’ good truth, as rheumatic as two dry toasts, you cannot one bear with another’s confirmities. What the good-year! One must bear, and that must be you, you are the weaker vessel, as they say, the emptier vessel.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead? There’s a whole merchant’s venture of Burdeaux stuff in him, you have not seen a hulk better stuff’d in the hold. Come, I’ll be friends with thee, Jack. Thou art going to the wars, and whether I shall ever see thee again or no, there is nobody cares.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Cheater, call you him? I will bar no honest man my house, nor no cheater, but I do not love swaggering, by my troth. I am the worse when one says swagger. Feel, masters, how I shake, look you, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: So you do, hostess.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Do I? Yea, in very truth, do I, and ’twere an aspen leaf. I cannot abide swagg’rers.

stagedir.dir: Enter Ancient Pistol and Bardolph and Boy Page.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I pray thee, Jack, be quiet, the rascal’s gone. Ah, you whoreson little valiant villain, you!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Are you not hurt i’ th’ groin? Methought ’a made a shrewd thrust at your belly.

speech.speaker: PAGE.
speech.line: The music is come, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Doll. A rascal bragging slave! The rogue fled from me like quicksilver.

speech.speaker: DOLL.
speech.line: I’ faith, and thou follow’dst him like a church. Thou whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig, when wilt thou leave fighting a’ days and foining a’ nights, and begin to patch up thine old body for heaven?

stagedir.dir: Enter, behind, Prince Henry and Poins, disguised.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: Peto, how now, what news?

speech.speaker: PETO.
speech.line: The King your father is at Westminster,
And there are twenty weak and wearied posts
Come from the north, and as I came along
I met and overtook a dozen captains,
Bare-headed, sweating, knocking at the taverns,
And asking every one for Sir John Falstaff.

speech.speaker: PRINCE.
speech.line: By heaven, Poins, I feel me much to blame
So idly to profane the precious time,
When tempest of commotion, like the south
Borne with black vapor, doth begin to melt
And drop upon our bare unarmed heads.
Give me my sword and cloak. Falstaff, good night.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Prince and Poins, Peto and Bardolph.

scene.line: More knocking at the door!
How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: You must away to court, sir, presently,
A dozen captains stay at door for you.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: Well, fare thee well. I have known thee these twenty-nine years, come peascod-time, but an honester and truer-hearted man—well, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Mistress Tearsheet!

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master.

speech.speaker: HOST.
speech.line: O, run, Doll, run, run, good Doll. Come.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Go call the Earls of Surrey and of Warwick;
But, ere they come, bid them o’er-read these letters
And well consider of them. Make good speed.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Many good morrows to your Majesty!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is it good morrow, lords?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: ’Tis one a’ clock, and past.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why then good morrow to you all, my lords.
Have you read o’er the letters that I sent you?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: We have, my liege.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then you perceive the body of our kingdom
How foul it is, what rank diseases grow,
And with what danger, near the heart of it.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: It is but as a body yet distempered,
Which to his former strength may be restored
With good advice and little medicine.
My Lord Northumberland will soon be cool’d.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: O God, that one might read the book of fate,
And see the revolution of the times
Make mountains level, and the continent,
Weary of solid firmness, melt itself
Into the sea, and other times to see
The beachy girdle of the ocean
Too wide for Neptune’s hips; how chance’s mocks
And changes fill the cup of alteration
With divers liquors! O, if this were seen,
The happiest youth, viewing his progress through,
What perils past, what crosses to ensue,
Would shut the book, and sit him down and die.
’Tis not ten years gone
Since Richard and Northumberland, great friends,
Did feast together, and in two year after
Were they at wars. It is but eight years since
This Percy was the man nearest my soul,
Who like a brother toil’d in my affairs,
And laid his love and life under my foot,
Yea, for my sake, even to the eyes of Richard
Gave him defiance. But which of you was by—

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come on, come on, come on, give me your hand, sir, give me your hand, sir. An early stirrer, by the rood! And how doth my good cousin Silence?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Good morrow, good cousin Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: And how doth my cousin, your bedfellow? And your fairest daughter and mine, my goddaughter Ellen?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Alas, a black woosel, cousin Shallow!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin William is become a good scholar. He is at Oxford still, is he not?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Indeed, sir, to my cost.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: ’A must then to the Inns a’ Court shortly. I was once of Clement’s Inn, where I think they will talk of mad Shallow yet.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: You were call’d lusty Shallow then, cousin.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By the mass, I was call’d any thing, and I would have done any thing indeed too, and roundly too. There was I, and little John Doit of Staffords hire, and black George Barnes, and Francis Pickbone, and Will Squele, a Cotsole man. You had not four such swingebucklers in all the Inns a’ Court again; and I may say to you, we knew where the bona robas were and had the best of them all at commandement. Then was Jack Falstaff, now Sir John, a boy, and page to Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: This Sir John, cousin, that comes hither anon about soldiers?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: The same Sir John, the very same. I see him break Scoggin’s head at the court-gate, when ’a was a crack not thus high; and the very same day did I fight with one Samson Stockfish, a fruiterer, behind Gray’s Inn. Jesu, Jesu, the mad days that I have spent! And to see how many of my old acquaintance are dead!

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: We shall all follow, cousin.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Certain, ’tis certain, very sure, very sure. Death, as the Psalmist saith, is certain to all, all shall die. How a good yoke of bullocks at Stamford fair?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: By my troth, I was not there.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Death is certain. Is old Double of your town living yet?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Dead, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Jesu, Jesu, dead! ’A drew a good bow, and dead! ’A shot a fine shoot. John a’ Gaunt lov’d him well, and betted much money on his head. Dead! ’A would have clapp’d i’ th’ clout at twelvescore, and carried you a forehand shaft a fourteen and fourteen and a half, that it would have done a man’s heart good to see. How a score of ewes now?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Thereafter as they be, a score of good ewes may be worth ten pounds.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: And is old Double dead?

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Here come two of Sir John Falstaff’s men, as I think.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bardolph and one with him.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: It is very just. Look, here comes good Sir John. Give me your good hand, give me your worship’s good hand. By my troth, you like well and bear your years very well. Welcome, good Sir John.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am glad to see you well, good Master Robert Shallow. Master Surecard, as I think?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: No, Sir John, it is my cousin Silence, in commission with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Good Master Silence, it well befits you should be of the peace.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: Your good worship is welcome.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fie, this is hot weather, gentlemen. Have you provided me here half a dozen sufficient men?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Marry, have we, sir. Will you sit?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Let me see them, I beseech you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Where’s the roll? Let me see, let me see, let me see. So, so, so, so, so, so, so; yea, marry, sir. Rafe Mouldy! Let them appear as I call; let them do so, let them do so. Let me see, where is Mouldy?

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Here, and’t please you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: What think you, Sir John? A good-limb’d fellow, young, strong, and of good friends.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Is thy name Mouldy?

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Yea, and’t please you.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Tis the more time thou wert us’d.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha! Most excellent, i’ faith! Things that are mouldy lack use. Very singular good, in faith, well said, Sir John, very well said.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Prick him.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: I was prick’d well enough before, and you could have let me alone. My old dame will be undone now for one to do her husbandry and her drudgery. You need not to have prick’d me, there are other men fitter to go out than I.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Go to, peace, Mouldy, you shall go. Mouldy, it is time you were spent.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: Spent?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Peace, fellow, peace, stand aside, know you where you are? For th’ other, Sir John, let me see: Simon Shadow!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, marry, let me have him to sit under, he’s like to be a cold soldier.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Where’s Shadow?

speech.speaker: SHAD.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shadow, whose son art thou?

speech.speaker: SHAD.
speech.line: My mother’s son, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thy mother’s son! Like enough, and thy father’s shadow. So the son of the female is the shadow of the male. It is often so indeed, but much of the father’s substance!

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Do you like him, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Shadow will serve for summer, prick him, aside for we have a number of shadows fill up the muster-book.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Thomas Wart!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Where’s he?

speech.speaker: WART.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Is thy name Wart?

speech.speaker: WART.
speech.line: Yea, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Thou art a very ragged wart.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Shall I prick him, Sir John?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: It were superfluous, for ’s apparel is built upon his back, and the whole frame stands upon pins. Prick him no more.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha! You can do it, sir, you can do it, I commend you well. Francis Feeble!

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: What trade art thou, Feeble?

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: A woman’s tailor, sir.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Shall I prick him, sir?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: You may, but if he had been a man’s tailor, he’d ’a’ prick’d you. Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemy’s battle as thou hast done in a woman’s petticoat?

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: I will do my good will, sir, you can have no more.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Well said, good woman’s tailor! Well said, courageous Feeble! Thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathful dove or most magnanimous mouse. Prick the woman’s tailor. Well, Master Shallow, deep, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: I would Wart might have gone, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would thou wert a man’s tailor, that thou mightst mend him and make him fit to go. I cannot put him to a private soldier that is the leader of so many thousands. Let that suffice, most forcible Feeble.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: It shall suffice, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I am bound to thee, reverend Feeble. Who is next?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Peter Bullcalf o’ th’ green!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Yea, marry, let’s see Bullcalf.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: Here, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Fore God, a likely fellow! Come prick Bullcalf till he roar again.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: O Lord, good my lord captain—

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What, dost thou roar before thou art prick’d?

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: O Lord, sir, I am a diseas’d man.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: What disease hast thou?

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: A whoreson cold, sir, a cough, sir, which I caught with ringing in the King’s affairs upon his coronation-day, sir.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come, thou shalt go to the wars in a gown. We will have away thy cold, and I will take such order that thy friends shall ring for thee. Is here all?

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Here is two more call’d than your number, you must have but four here, sir. And so I pray you go in with me to dinner.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come, I will go drink with you, but I cannot tarry dinner. I am glad to see you, by my troth, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: O Sir John, do you remember since we lay all night in the Windmill in Saint George’s Field?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: No more of that, Master Shallow, no more of that.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, ’twas a merry night. And is Jane Nightwork alive?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: She lives, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: She never could away with me.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Never, never, she would always say she could not abide Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: By the mass, I could anger her to th’ heart. She was then a bona roba. Doth she hold her own well?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Old, old, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Nay, she must be old, she cannot choose but be old, certain she’s old, and had Robin Nightwork by old Nightwork before I came to Clement’s Inn.

speech.speaker: SIL.
speech.line: That’s fifty-five year ago.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Ha, cousin Silence, that thou hadst seen that that this knight and I have seen! Ha, Sir John, said I well?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: We have heard the chimes at midnight, Master Shallow.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: That we have, that we have, that we have, in faith, Sir John, we have. Our watch-word was “Hem, boys!” Come let’s to dinner, come let’s to dinner. Jesus, the days that we have seen! Come, come.

speech.speaker: BULL.
speech.line: Good Master Corporate Bardolph, stand my friend, and here’s four Harry ten shillings in French crowns for you. In very truth, sir, I had as live be hang’d, sir, as go, and yet for mine own part, sir, I do not care, but rather, because I am unwilling, and for mine own part, have a desire to stay with my friends, else, sir, I did not care for mine own part so much.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Go to, stand aside.

speech.speaker: MOUL.
speech.line: And, good Master Corporal Captain, for my old dame’s sake stand my friend. She has nobody to do any thing about her when I am gone, and she is old, and cannot help herself. You shall have forty, sir.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Go to, stand aside.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: By my troth I care not; a man can die but once, we owe God a death. I’ll ne’er bear a base mind. And’t be my dest’ny, so; and’t be not, so. No man’s too good to serve ’s prince, and let it go which way it will, he that dies this year is quit for the next.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Well said, th’ art a good fellow.

speech.speaker: FEE.
speech.line: Faith, I’ll bear no base mind.
Sir, a word with you.
I have three pound to free Mouldy and Bullcalf.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Go to, well.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Come, Sir John, which four will you have?

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Do you choose for me.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Marry, then, Mouldy, Bullcalf, Feeble, and Shadow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Mouldy and Bullcalf! For you, Mouldy, stay at home till you are past service; and for your part, Bullcalf, grow till you come unto it. I will none of you.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir John, Sir John, do not yourself wrong. They are your likeliest men, and I would have you serv’d with the best.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Will you tell me, Master Shallow, how to choose a man? Care I for the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk, and big assemblance of a man? Give me the spirit, Master Shallow. Here’s Wart, you see what a ragged appearance it is. ’A shall charge you and discharge you with the motion of a pewterer’s hammer, come off and on swifter than he that gibbets on the brewer’s bucket. And this same half-fac’d fellow, Shadow, give me this man. He presents no mark to the enemy, the foeman may with as great aim level at the edge of a penknife. And for a retreat, how swiftly will this Feeble the woman’s tailor run off! O, give me the spare men, and spare me the great ones. Put me a caliver into Wart’s hand, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: BARD.
speech.line: Hold, Wart, traverse! Thas, thas, thas.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Come manage me your caliver. So—very well, go to, very good, exceeding good. O, give me always a little, lean, old, chopp’d, bald shot. Well said, i’ faith, Wart, th’ art a good scab. Hold, there’s a tester for thee.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: He is not his craft’s master, he doth not do it right. I remember at Mile-end Green, when I lay at Clement’s Inn—I was then Sir Dagonet in Arthur’s show—there was a little quiver fellow, and ’a would manage you his piece thus, and ’a would about and about, and come you in and come you in. “Rah, tah, tah,” would ’a say, “bounce,” would ’a say, and away again would ’a go, and again would ’a come. I shall ne’er see such a fellow.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: These fellows woll do well, Master Shallow. God keep you, Master Silence, I will not use many words with you. Fare you well, gentlemen both, I thank you. I must a dozen mile tonight. Bardolph, give the soldiers coats.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Sir John, the Lord bless you! God prosper your affairs! God send us peace! At your return visit our house, let our old acquaintance be renew’d. Peradventure I will with ye to the court.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: ’Fore God, would you would.

speech.speaker: SHAL.
speech.line: Go to, I have spoke at a word. God keep you!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: Fare you well, gentle gentlemen.
On, Bardolph, lead the men away.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Within the Forest of Gaultree.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Archbishop of York, Mowbray, Lord Bardolph, Hastings, and others, within the forest of Gaultree.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Now, what news?

speech.speaker: MESS.
speech.line: West of this forest, scarcely off a mile,
In goodly form comes on the enemy,
And by the ground they hide, I judge their number
Upon or near the rate of thirty thousand.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: The just proportion that we gave them out.
Let us sway on and face them in the field.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: What well-appointed leader fronts us here?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: I think it is my Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Health and fair greeting from our general,
The Prince, Lord John and Duke of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Say on, my Lord of Westmorland, in peace,
What doth concern your coming.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Then, my lord,
Unto your Grace do I in chief address
The substance of my speech. If that rebellion
Came like itself, in base and abject routs,
Led on by bloody youth, guarded with rage,
And countenanc’d by boys and beggary—
I say, if damn’d commotion so appear’d
In his true, native, and most proper shape,
You, reverend father, and these noble lords
Had not been here to dress the ugly form
Of base and bloody insurrection
With your fair honors. You, Lord Archbishop,
Whose see is by a civil peace maintain’d,
Whose beard the silver hand of peace hath touch’d,
Whose learning and good letters peace hath tutor’d,
Whose white investments figure innocence,
The dove, and very blessed spirit of peace,
Wherefore do you so ill translate yourself
Out of the speech of peace that bears such grace,
Into the harsh and boist’rous tongue of war?
Turning your books to graves, your ink to blood,
Your pens to lances, and your tongue divine
To a loud trumpet and a point of war?

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Wherefore do I this? So the question stands.
Briefly, to this end: we are all diseas’d,
And with our surfeiting and wanton hours
Have brought ourselves into a burning fever,
And we must bleed for it; of which disease
Our late King Richard (being infected) died.
But, my most noble Lord of Westmorland,
I take not on me here as a physician,
Nor do I as an enemy to peace
Troop in the throngs of military men;
But rather show a while like fearful war
To diet rank minds sick of happiness,
And purge th’ obstructions which begin to stop
Our very veins of life. Hear me more plainly.
I have in equal balance justly weigh’d
What wrongs our arms may do, what wrongs we suffer,
And find our griefs heavier than our offenses.
We see which way the stream of time doth run,
And are enforc’d from our most quiet there
By the rough torrent of occasion,
And have the summary of all our griefs
(When time shall serve) to show in articles;
Which long ere this we offer’d to the King,
And might by no suit gain our audience.
When we are wrong’d and would unfold our griefs,
We are denied access unto his person
Even by those men that most have done us wrong.
The dangers of the days but newly gone,
Whose memory is written on the earth
With yet appearing blood, and the examples
Of every minute’s instance (present now)
Hath put us in these ill-beseeming arms,
Not to break peace, or any branch of it,
But to establish here a peace indeed,
Concurring both in name and quality.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: When ever yet was your appeal denied?
Wherein have you been galled by the King?
What peer hath been suborn’d to grate on you?
That you should seal this lawless bloody book
Of forg’d rebellion with a seal divine.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: My brother general, the commonwealth,
I make my quarrel in particular.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: There is no need of any such redress,
Or if there were, it not belongs to you.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Why not to him in part, and to us all
That feel the bruises of the days before,
And suffer the condition of these times
To lay a heavy and unequal hand
Upon our honors?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: O, my good Lord Mowbray,
Construe the times to their necessities,
And you shall say, indeed, it is the time,
And not the King, that doth you injuries.
Yet, for your part, it not appears to me,
Either from the King or in the present time,
That you should have an inch of any ground
To build a grief on. Were you not restor’d
To all the Duke of Norfolk’s signories,
Your noble and right well-rememb’red father’s?

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: What thing, in honor, had my father lost,
That need to be reviv’d and breath’d in me?
The King that lov’d him, as the state stood then,
Was force perforce compell’d to banish him;
And then that Henry Bullingbrook and he,
Being mounted and both roused in their seats,
Their neighing coursers daring of the spur,
Their armed staves in charge, their beavers down,
Their eyes of fire sparkling through sights of steel,
And the loud trumpet blowing them together;
Then, then, when there was nothing could have stay’d
My father from the breast of Bullingbrook,
O, when the King did throw his warder down
(His own life hung upon the staff he threw),
Then threw he down himself and all their lives
That by indictment and by dint of sword
Have since miscarried under Bullingbrook.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: You speak, Lord Mowbray, now you know not what.
The Earl of Herford was reputed then
In England the most valiant gentleman.
Who knows on whom fortune would then have smil’d?
But if your father had been victor there,
He ne’er had borne it out of Coventry;
For all the country in a general voice
Cried hate upon him; and all their prayers and love
Were set on Herford, whom they doted on
And bless’d and grac’d and did, more than the King—
But this is mere digression from my purpose.
Here come I from our princely general
To know your griefs, to tell you from his Grace
That he will give you audience, and wherein
It shall appear that your demands are just,
You shall enjoy them, every thing set off
That might so much as think you enemies.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: But he hath forc’d us to compel this offer,
And it proceeds from policy, not love.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Mowbray, you overween to take it so;
This offer comes from mercy, not from fear.
For lo, within a ken our army lies:
Upon mine honor, all too confident
To give admittance to a thought of fear.
Our battle is more full of names than yours,
Our men more perfect in the use of arms,
Our armor all as strong, our cause the best;
Then reason will our hearts should be as good.
Say you not then our offer is compell’d.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Well, by my will we shall admit no parley.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: That argues but the shame of your offense:
A rotten case abides no handling.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Hath the Prince John a full commission,
In very ample virtue of his father,
To hear and absolutely to determine
Of what conditions we shall stand upon?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: That is intended in the general’s name.
I muse you make so slight a question.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Then take, my Lord of Westmorland, this schedule,
For this contains our general grievances:
Each several article herein redress’d,
All members of our cause, both here and hence,
That are ensinewed to this action
Acquitted by a true substantial form
And present execution of our wills—
To us and to our purposes confin’d
We come within our aweful banks again,
And knit our powers to the arm of peace.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: This will I show the general. Please you, lords,
In sight of both our battles we may meet,
And either end in peace, which God so frame!
Or to the place of diff’rence call the swords
Which must decide it.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: My lord, we will do so.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: There is a thing within my bosom tells me
That no conditions of our peace can stand.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Fear you not that; if we can make our peace
Upon such large terms and so absolute
As our conditions shall consist upon,
Our peace shall stand as firm as rocky mountains.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Yea, but our valuation shall be such
That every slight and false-derived cause,
Yea, every idle, nice, and wanton reason,
Shall to the King taste of this action,
That were our royal faiths martyrs in love,
We shall be winnow’d with so rough a wind
That even our corn shall seem as light as chaff,
And good from bad find no partition.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: No, no, my lord, note this: the King is weary
Of dainty and such picking grievances,
For he hath found to end one doubt by death
Revives two greater in the heirs of life;
And therefore will he wipe his tables clean
And keep no tell-tale to his memory
That may repeat and history his loss
To new remembrance; for full well he knows
He cannot so precisely weed this land
As his misdoubts present occasion.
His foes are so enrooted with his friends
That, plucking to unfix an enemy,
He doth unfasten so and shake a friend,
So that this land, like an offensive wife
That hath enrag’d him on to offer strokes,
As he is striking, holds his infant up
And hangs resolv’d correction in the arm
That was uprear’d to execution.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Besides, the King hath wasted all his rods
On late offenders, that he now doth lack
The very instruments of chastisement,
So that his power, like to a fangless lion,
May offer, but not hold.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: ’Tis very true,
And therefore be assur’d, my good Lord Marshal,
If we do now make our atonement well,
Our peace will, like a broken limb united,
Grow stronger for the breaking.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Be it so.
Here is return’d my Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: The Prince is here at hand. Pleaseth your lordship
To meet his Grace just distance ’tween our armies.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Your Grace of York, in God’s name then set forward.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Before, and greet his Grace.—My lord, we come.

stagedir.dir: They march about the stage and then move forward to meet Prince John.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the Forest of Gaultree.

stagedir.dir: Enter Prince John of Lancaster and his army.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: To you, my noble Lord of Westmorland.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: I pledge your Grace, and if you knew what pains
I have bestowed to breed this present peace,
You would drink freely. But my love to ye
Shall show itself more openly hereafter.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: I do not doubt you.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: I am glad of it.
Health to my lord, and gentle cousin, Mowbray.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: You wish me health in very happy season,
For I am on the sudden something ill.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Against ill chances men are ever merry,
But heaviness foreruns the good event.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Therefore be merry, coz, since sudden sorrow
Serves to say thus, some good thing comes tomorrow.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Believe me, I am passing light in spirit.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: So much the worse, if your own rule be true.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: The word of peace is rend’red. Hark how they shout!

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: This had been cheerful after victory.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: A peace is of the nature of a conquest,
For then both parties nobly are subdued,
And neither party loser.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Go, my lord,
And let our army be discharged too.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: My lord, our army is dispers’d already:
Like youthful steers unyok’d, they take their courses
East, west, north, south, or, like a school broke up,
Each hurries toward his home and sporting-place.

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Good tidings, my Lord Hastings! For the which
I do arrest thee, traitor, of high treason,
And you, Lord Archbishop, and you, Lord Mowbray,
Of capital treason I attach you both.

speech.speaker: MOWB.
speech.line: Is this proceeding just and honorable?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Is your assembly so?

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Will you thus break your faith?

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: I pawn’d thee none.
I promis’d you redress of these same grievances
Whereof you did complain, which, by mine honor,
I will perform with a most Christian care.
But for you rebels, look to taste the due
Meet for rebellion and such acts as yours.
Most shallowly did you these arms commence,
Fondly brought here and foolishly sent hence.
Strike up our drums, pursue the scatt’red stray;
God, and not we, hath safely fought today.
Some guard these traitors to the block of death,
Treason’s true bed and yielder-up of breath.

scene.scenelocation: Yorkshire. Another part of the Forest of Gaultree.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Excursions. Enter Falstaff and Colevile, meeting.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: The heat is past, follow no further now;
Call in the powers, good cousin Westmorland.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Now, have you left pursuit?

speech.speaker: WEST.
speech.line: Retreat is made and execution stay’d.

speech.speaker: P. JOHN.
speech.line: Send Colevile with his confederates
To York, to present execution.
Blunt, lead him hence, and see you guard him sure.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Blunt and others with Colevile.

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: I would you had the wit, ’twere better than your dukedom. Good faith, this same young sober-blooded boy doth not love me, nor a man cannot make him laugh, but that’s no marvel, he drinks no wine. There’s never none of these demure boys come to any proof, for thin drink doth so over-cool their blood, and making many fish-meals, that they fall into a kind of male green-sickness, and then when they marry, they get wenches. They are generally fools and cowards, which some of us should be too, but for inflammation. A good sherris-sack hath a twofold operation in it. It ascends me into the brain, dries me there all the foolish and dull and crudy vapors which environ it, makes it apprehensive, quick, forgetive, full of nimble, fiery, and delectable shapes, which deliver’d o’er to the voice, the tongue, which is the birth, becomes excellent wit. The second property of your excellent sherris is the warming of the blood, which before (cold and settled) left the liver white and pale, which is the badge of pusillanimity and cowardice; but the sherris warms it, and makes it course from the inwards to the parts’ extremes. It illumineth the face, which as a beacon gives warning to all the rest of this little kingdom, man, to arm, and then the vital commoners and inland petty spirits muster me all to their captain, the heart, who great and puff’d up with this retinue, doth any deed of courage; and this valor comes of sherris. So that skill in the weapon is nothing without sack (for that sets it a-work) and learning a mere hoard of gold kept by a devil, till sack commences it and sets it in act and use. Hereof comes it that Prince Harry is valiant, for the cold blood he did naturally inherit of his father, he hath, like lean, sterile, and bare land, manur’d, husbanded, and till’d with excellent endeavor of drinking good and good store of fertile sherris, that he is become very hot and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, the first humane principle I would teach them should be, to forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Now, lords, if God doth give successful end
To this debate that bleedeth at our doors,
We will our youth lead on to higher fields,
And draw no swords but what are sanctified.
Our navy is address’d, our power collected,
Our substitutes in absence well invested,
And every thing lies level to our wish.
Only, we want a little personal strength;
And pause us till these rebels, now afoot,
Come underneath the yoke of government.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Both which we doubt not but your Majesty
Shall soon enjoy.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Humphrey, my son of Gloucester,
Where is the Prince your brother?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I think he’s gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And how accompanied?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I do not know, my lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: No, my good lord, he is in presence here.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: What would my lord and father?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Nothing but well to thee, Thomas of Clarence.
How chance thou art not with the Prince thy brother?
He loves thee, and thou dost neglect him, Thomas.
Thou hast a better place in his affection
Than all thy brothers. Cherish it, my boy;
And noble offices thou mayst effect
Of mediation, after I am dead,
Between his greatness and thy other brethren.
Therefore omit him not, blunt not his love,
Nor lose the good advantage of his grace
By seeming cold or careless of his will,
For he is gracious if he be observ’d,
He hath a tear for pity, and a hand
Open as day for meting charity;
Yet notwithstanding, being incens’d, he is flint,
As humorous as winter, and as sudden
As flaws congealed in the spring of day.
His temper therefore must be well observ’d.
Chide him for faults, and do it reverently,
When you perceive his blood inclin’d to mirth;
But, being moody, give him time and scope,
Till that his passions, like a whale on ground,
Confound themselves with working. Learn this, Thomas,
And thou shalt prove a shelter to thy friends,
A hoop of gold to bind thy brothers in,
That the united vessel of their blood,
Mingled with venom of suggestion
(As, force perforce, the age will pour it in),
Shall never leak, though it do work as strong
As aconitum or rash gunpowder.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I shall observe him with all care and love.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why art thou not at Windsor with him, Thomas?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: He is not there today, he dines in London.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And how accompanied? Canst thou tell that?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: With Poins, and other his continual followers.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Most subject is the fattest soil to weeds,
And he, the noble image of my youth,
Is overspread with them; therefore my grief
Stretches itself beyond the hour of death.
The blood weeps from my heart when I do shape,
In forms imaginary, th’ unguided days
And rotten times that you shall look upon,
When I am sleeping with my ancestors.
For when his headstrong riot hath no curb,
When rage and hot blood are his counsellors,
When means and lavish manners meet together,
O, with what wings shall his affections fly
Towards fronting peril and oppos’d decay!

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: My gracious lord, you look beyond him quite:
The Prince but studies his companions
Like a strange tongue, wherein, to gain the language,
’Tis needful that the most immodest word
Be look’d upon and learnt, which once attain’d,
Your Highness knows, comes to no further use
But to be known and hated. So, like gross terms,
The Prince will in the perfectness of time
Cast off his followers, and their memory
Shall as a pattern or a measure live,
By which his Grace must mete the lives of other,
Turning past evils to advantages.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: ’Tis seldom when the bee doth leave her comb
In the dead carrion.
Look here’s more news.

speech.speaker: HAR.
speech.line: From enemies heavens keep your Majesty,
And, when they stand against you, may they fall
As those that I am come to tell you of!
The Earl Northumberland and the Lord Bardolph,
With a great power of English and of Scots,
Are by the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown.
The manner and true order of the fight
This packet, please it you, contains at large.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And wherefore should these good news make me sick?
Will Fortune never come with both hands full,
But write her fair words still in foulest terms?
She either gives a stomach and no food—
